title: Boston Spa Walk Route

images.title: Leslie / Bridge over the River Wharfe - Boston Spa
images.caption: Bridge over the River Wharfe in Boston Spa

images.title: DS Pugh / Wharfe Bridge
images.caption: Wharfe Bridge, east of the town.

images.title: Gordon Hatton / The Wharfe at Newton Kyme
images.caption: The Wharfe at Newton Kyme. In recent years, archaeological work on the riverbank has revealed the site of a medieval ford which was on a route between the [now disappeared] villages of Toulston and Easdike

images.title: Gordon Hatton / Newton Kyme castle
images.caption: Newton Kyme castle. The slight remains of this 13th century castle are now a 'garden ornament' within the grounds of the hall.

images.title: Gordon Hatton / The Dower House, Newton Kyme
images.caption: The Dower House, Newton Kyme. A fine house that looks out over Newton Hall Park. The architectural guide says 18th century, but the style looks earlier.

images.title: Gordon Hatton / Newton Hall Park
images.caption: Newton Hall Park Parkland to the south of Newton Hall. Plenty of evidence of ridge and furrow in the park. Photograph taken in the autumn of 2007

images.title: Mtaylor848 / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0)
images.caption: Stew and Oyster, High Street, Boston Spa.

description: The village of Boston Spa is located in the north eastern corner of the city of Leeds. There's some nice trails along the River Wharfe and the interesting neighbouring village of Thorpe Arch and Newton Kyme to visit. The attractive village has some fine Georgian architecture and several good shops and pubs in the centre. This walk explores the area to the east of the village, following the river to Newton Kyme and its castle ruins. It's easy walking with lovely views of the peaceful river, the rushing weir and the surrounding countryside. The walk starts on the Wharfe in Boston Spa and heads east along a section of the Ebor Way . You'll pass Ingle Bank Wood and Wharfe Bridge before coming to the site of an old Roman Fort. The path turns south here before picking up Croft Lane to take you into Newton Kyme. Here you can follow the path to the ruins fof Kyme Castle next to the river. The route then retraces its steps back to Wharfe Bridge where you can cross to the other side to visit the village of Thorp Arch, which sits opposite to Boston Spa. From here you cross another bridge to return to Boston Spa.
